author: @banamailat_BM
text: When I decided to become a Data analyst 1 year ago, I met you while searching for an answer to "where should I start?". I'm following you for these thorough and honest reviews. And I learned a lot from you. In one of your comments, when I asked if I was too old for these jobs, you said that age is just a number. Remember? :)). Your statement was really encouraging for me. Really thanks.   Clearly; If you want to have a job, SQL, Excel, Tableau, Power BI, Phyton or R, which are the entry-level tools you learn from the courses, if you do not have real-life studies in at least 3 of them, the probability of finding a job is very low. I learned this from you, and real life confirms this. No employer just looks at this certificate and asks for your bank account number. That's why, after getting the original analytical certificate, I spend my time, to sharpening my skills which I gain with course, to get specialist certificates instead of general certificates. I would be wasting my time if it weren't for those who share their honest and impartial personal experiences like you. I received my certificate in January/2023. Now I have come a long way in SQL, R (I started with the original Google analytics certificate and I love this language.) and Tableau. I am preparing for the Tableau Certification Proctored exam. You are an important figure for this community. Thanks again.

Enjoy the content and application/presentation.

author: @joeyoung7276
text: Is it possible for you to comment on "the data janitor" Mike West?  He makes a lot of bold claims and does seem pretty knowledgeable on the subject.  I find it hard to believe he is just wrong about everything he says but at the same time I am unsure if he is just trying to push his own data courses ( Logikbot ).  His courses focus primarily on SQL I believe which sounds great.  He says these certificates of "completion" are worthless to an employer and even look bad in cases.  Instead he says that you should go for a certification in the field which is very different from these online courses.  Would it be wise to just gain as much knowledge as you can from coursera, and or logikbot, and then try to take one of these certification tests at a university or wherever they offer them?  I'm not trying to bash his ideas or have you do the ladder but in my opinion he is a little on the hardcore side of the field and maybe doesn't realize that some people would be very happy with an entry level position to start , grow, learn.  I have an old bachelors  degree in C.S. and would be very happy to land anything in the data field I have been out of the loop for some time now and I would just like to know which direction to go and waste minimal time if possible.  Thank you for your videos and time you spend helping others. I think you do a wonderful job on here at explaining things and  I hope to hear back from you ( or anyone ) on this topic.

author: @ShowBizJunkie
text: I am taking Google Certificate in Data Analysis right now. Befire this, I had taken SQl and Tablaeu basic. I am doing this for certificate and for discipline/order. To be good on mybown, I am having difficulty finding how to practice beginners knowledge and to gain intermediate knowledge. I was getting overwhelmed and also got me a job and became busy with it. For the whole year, I could not use my data analysis skills. So I decided to take the course. It is very basic. It wastes a lot of your time in useless exercises that dont teach you anything. Instead of making you create more small projects to learn better.  The exam questions are okay. Some of them are good, some are ridiculous but better than the opinion essays you have to write which in my opinion is waste of time

text: It is out of print now, but the best series I ever read on SQL Development was Joes2Pros 2012 ... granted its focused on T-SQL. author: @business_and_data
text: Something interesting to know is that here in Mexico, many of the recruiters have no idea what they are looking for, for companies here in M√©xico or companies in the USA, If you show them many certificates and documents that prove that you know about the subject, it is more likely that they will hire you, another detail that goes from the The hand is that many companies (large, medium and small) believe that they know what they need and believe that they know what they are looking for, so it will be common to see many hybrid profiles, something like a data analyst doing business analyst work or a data scientist who works as a business intelligence analyst and many similar things, however, on many occasions they ask for requirements that are never used, it is something strange, don't you think?

author: @eluxury2
text: I'm currently enrolled in the Google Data Analytics course and I'm almost done with it. However, I'm not really interested in taking the Google Advanced Analytics course, and I wouldn't really recommend Google courses to others. There are quite a few errors in the course, and Google doesn't seem to update it regularly.  Also, there are gaps in the content, and many students have mentioned feeling confused about certain course materials.

author: @frothylube491
text: I completed the original Data Analytics certification about 3 months ago. The course is very good for beginners, however, I think Google needs to take off the aspect of ‚Äúbe job ready in 3-6 months‚Äù and ‚Äúconnect with employers.‚Äù Most of the jobs on the platform are requiring a degree and prior experience, and didn‚Äôt care about any of my work that I‚Äôd done from completing the certificate.   I wasn‚Äôt expecting to get a job because of the certificate but out of the small handful of interviews I got, which were for entry level positions, they all denied me on the basis of ‚Äúlacking experience/not the right degree.‚Äù Even though one recruiter commented ‚Äúthat‚Äôs impressive you learned how to do this type of work within 4 months.‚Äù Truly sucks that Google isn‚Äôt trying to help more with these programs and actually help people land some jobs

author: @Geomaverick124
text: I think these courses are supposed to be taken in addition to the first course. If you take the course by itself then you will wind up missing a bunch of stuff. I would suggest to take all 3 and take the META Database Course or the SQL for Data Science and then get a tool cert like Power BI or Tableau. If short on time, take the Original Google DA certificate, META Database Engineer Certificate, and get the Tableau Data Analyst certification...you will still need to build plenty of projects. The certification will just set you a part
